div.l: Him byhoues serue him self þat has no swayn
Or elles he is a fool as clerkes seyn
Oure Manciple I hope he wil be deed
Swa werkes him ay the wanges in his heed
I pray ȝow spede vs hethen þat ȝe may
It schall be don quod simken be my fay
What will ȝe doo while þat it is in hande
By god right by the hoper will I stande
Quod Iohn ⁊and see how gates þe corn gas Inne
Ȝit sawh I neủere be my fader kynne
How þat the hoper wagges till ⁊and fra
Aleyn answerde Iohn wilt þou swa
Than will I be bynethe be my crowne
And see how gates þe mele falles adowne
In to the trough þat sall be my disporte
Quod Iohn in faath I may ben of ȝoure sorte
I is as ille a Millere as ar ȝe
This Millere smyled of here nycete
And þoght all þis is doon but for a wile
Thei wene þat no man may þem begile
But be my thrift ȝit schal I blere here eighe
For all þe sleight in here philosophie
The more queynte Crekes þat þei make
The more wil I stele whan I take
In stede of flour ȝit wil I ȝeue hem brenne
The grettest clerkes ben noght wisest men
As whilom to the wolf þus spak the hare
Of all here arte coıı̄unte I noght a tare
¶ Out of the dore he goth ful priuely
Whan þat he sawh his tyme softely
He loketh vp ⁊and doıı̄un til he haþ foıı̄unde
The Clerkes hors þ̉ere as it stood I boıı̄unde
Behynde þe Mille vnder a leuesel
And to the hors he goth him faire ⁊and wel
He strepeth of the bridel right anon
And whan the hors was loos he gynneth to goon
Toward the fenne þere wilde mares renne
And forth with wehe þorgh þicke ⁊and þorgh thenne
